qas.question: What is another name for unicode?

answers.text: the corresponding ISO/IEC 10646: Universal Character Set

qas.question: Using precomposed or combining characters is called what?
All LAtin characters required by POJ can be represented by what?

plausible_answers.text: the corresponding ISO/IEC 10646: Universal Character Set)

qas.question: What is another term for interpunct?

plausible_answers.text: the vowel akin to but more open than o, written with a dot above right
to encode a new combining character dot above right

qas.question: Before June 2004, what proposal has been made to the ISO/IEC?
What can all vowels required by POJ be represented by?
What is expected to follow using diacritics?

context: All Latin characters required by Pe̍h-ōe-jī can be represented using <a2_0><b6_0>Unicode<b6_0/><a2_0/> (or <a0_0><b3_0>the corresponding ISO/IEC 10646: Universal Character Set<a0_0/>)<b3_0/>, using precomposed or combining (<a1_0>diacritics<a1_0/>) characters. Prior to June 2004, <b4_0>the vowel akin to but more open than o, written with a dot above right<b4_0/>, was not encoded. The usual workaround was to use the (stand-alone; spacing) character Interpunct (U+00B7, ·) or less commonly the combining character dot above (U+0307). As these are far from ideal, since 1997 proposals have been submitted to the ISO/IEC working group in charge of ISO/IEC 10646—namely, ISO/IEC JTC1/SC2/WG2—<b5_0>to encode a new combining character dot above right<b5_0/>. This is now officially assigned to U+0358 (see documents N1593, N2507, N2628, N2699, and N2713). <b7_0>Font support<b7_0/> is expected to follow.
